DOC.HEAD: Students In Home Of `Amerika' Hear From Soviet Counterparts
DOC.TEXT: Glasnost has come to the home of ``Amerika,'' a 1986 television mini-series that depicted fictitious life in the United States after a Soviet takeover. Techumseh high school and elementary students recently began receiving responses to letters they wrote in August to students in Ryazan, 150 miles southwest of Moscow. Teachers are hoping the letters educate their students about the vastness of the world and about the society and politics of the Soviet Union, which had ``taken over'' Tecumseh during the filming of the mini-series in this southeastern Nebraska town of 1,900. ``I hope they get a better understanding of the world _ that it's a much bigger place than just Tecumseh, and that people around the world do similar things,'' said Janene Bartels, a first-grade teacher who helped initiate the project. High school English teacher Sheryl Allen said world politics seemed too distant for most of today's students. ``They're more concerned with what they're doing this weekend or what they're doing after the basketball game,'' Allen said. ``I'm hoping this might personalize it for them so that they'll turn on the news at night.'' Students in Allen's senior English classes received individual responses, while students in Bartels' first-grade class received one letter for the entire class, complete with photos of the class and Ryazan. The letters already have dispelled some stereotypes. Jamie Carson, a 17-year-old senior, said she perceived the Soviet Union as ``cold, gray and very strict'' but discovered that teen interests in music, clothes and sports were very similar. Soviet students mentioned Billy Joel and Michael Jackson as rock music idols, and talked of brands of clothing available in America. Mark Sherman, a 17-year-old senior, said he was amazed that his pen pal, a 16-year-old aspiring actress, was so stylishly dressed, and that her photograph had appeared in a national magazine. ``I had the impression there were people walking around the streets with guns,'' Sherman said. He and the other senior English students said they hoped they could dispell some myths about Americans, too. The letter exchange was intitiated by Col. Barney Oldfield, a Johnson County native who is now a Beverly Hills, Calif., author, publicist and consultant on Soviet affairs to the Litton Corp. The wife of Oldfield's Russian interpreter, Galina Korzhikova, is an English teacher in Ryazan. Bartels said she hoped the student letter exchange would pay dividends in promoting better U.S.-Soviet relations. ``Maybe by the time they grow up, communications with Russia will be very open,'' she said. ``But for now, it's a start.''
